body.p: is able to export documents as PDF employing Oxygen PDF Chemistry, a powerful engine who's output can be easily customizable through CSS.

It allows to print as PDF the edited document as is rendered in the author mode but it also allows to export to PDF based on XML to PDF with CSS transformation scenarios defined in the framework that may contain special publishing styles.

section.title: Enabling PDF Preview Support
section.p:
The Web Author PDF support can be enabled by installing the Web Author Publishing plugin that can be found in the Download Connectors/Plugins webpage. Make sure that you read and understand the terms and conditions of its end-user license agreement. Once installed and enabled, two actions are contributed to the Web Author interface (available in the More drop-down menu):
Print - generates a PDF preview from the current document and prints it. The PDF is generated using the same CSS files used by the editor.
Export as PDF - downloads a PDF preview version of the document based on the framework configuration:
By default, the editor styles are used.
If one or more XML to PDF with CSS publishing scenarios are configured, they appear in a sub-menu of the Export as PDF menu item. Those scenarios are based on Oxygen PDF Chemistry.

section.title: Notes About Configuring the Plugin in the Administration Page
section.p: When configuring the plugin in the Administration Page, the PDF generation invokes an external process on the server. It includes its own configuration page where you can configure:

ul.li: The memory allocated to a publishing process.
The maximum number of concurrent publishing processes.

section.note: The content communicated to and from the publishing process is encrypted.

section.title: Configuring the CSS
section.p: Since the conversion to PDF is done using Oxygen PDF Chemistry, it is based on the CSS files specified in the framework.

ThePrint action uses strictly the CSS files used to render the document in editor. The Export as PDF action uses the CSS files defined in the XML to PDF Transformation with CSS transformation scenarios, a Oxygen PDF Chemistry scenario.
Note that frameworks can be customized using Oxygen XML Editor/Author, from the "Document type" dialog from Options/Document Type Association/[your-framework].

ul.li: You can use media print {} rules to configure CSS rules that apply only for generating PDF.
For DITA, a file located at css/webauthor/p-dita.css is also loaded along with the editor styles.
You can use any CSS extension supported by the Oxygen PDF Chemistry engine.

The PDF generation engine will work on a resolved document. If your content uses DITA conrefs, XInclude, or another content reference mechanism, the references will be expanded before the file is sent to the CMS.
Links to other XML files will not work in the generated PDF. You may want to customize your CSS to handle this.
Fonts that cover the characters in the document have to be installed on the server that run Web Author. For example, see: Localization.
